statement:
Consider the differential equation $$x'=f(x)
\label{eq}$$ where $f$ is a $C^1$ vector field. Assume that $x_0$ is a
hyperbolic equilibrium of $f$. Denote $\Phi_t(x)$ the flow of (\[eq\])
through $x$ at time $t$. Then there exists a homeomorphism
$\varphi(x)=x+h(x)$ with $h$ bouded, such that
$$\varphi\circ e^{tDf(x_0)}=\Phi_t\circ\varphi$$ is a sufficiently small
neighboorhood of $x_0$.

This fundamental theorem in the qualitative analysis of nonlinear
differential equations states that, in a small neighborhood of $x_0$,
the flow of the nonlinear equation (\[eq\]) is qualitatively similar to
that of the linear system $x'=Df(x_0)x$.
